data.title: Drishti Combines AI and Video to Improve Manufacturing Operations
data.snippet:
The bulk of manufacturing is done by people, says Akella, and before now there has not been much data coming from the manual lines operating within a manufacturing facility. But with Drishti’s technology data can be collected and visibility can be given into an operation.

This allows companies to better analyze what processes may need to be improved and how they can go about doing so. It also offers opportunities to improve training by showing workers video of proper and improper procedures. Issues can be addressed in real time and from far distances using this technology, further benefiting manufacturers.

Read our Q&A with Prasad Akella to learn more about Drishti's technology and the benefits of using AI and video in manufacturing operations.

Manufacturers struggle to optimize human tasks at scale. Some believe human efficiency has peaked. data.title: Women in the Digital Industry: The Long Road of Drishti Maharjan
data.snippet:
What's so exciting about the field? "Being able to create something innovative with the help of a laptop and a few codes is really fascinating," she said. At Jacobs University, she also discovered her enthusiasm for hackathons. These are competitions in which participants have to find a creative, technical solution to a specific problem within a limited time. "Amazing innovations often come out of those," Drishti said. She was so taken with it that in 2019 she and some fellow students from Nepal set up their country's first international hackathon, Everest Hack. The event was a huge success. Now, the hackathon culture is growing in Nepal as well. [...] Most of the participants even in the hackathons she attended were men, of course. "As a child, I was often told that certain subjects were only for boys," Drishti recalled. For girls, she said, there was a lack of support; there were also no female teachers in the relevant subjects, no female role models. "In some classes at school, I was sometimes the only girl among 40 boys. That felt weird."

That changed at Jacobs University, at least a little. "I was super happy when I suddenly discovered fellow female students in my classes." However, her friends were quick to point out to her that men dominate math, science and technical subjects in Germany, too. "There just needs to be more support for women, not just in Nepal, but here too." [...] She also received guidance during her time at the university, for example from Peter Zaspel, Professor of Computer Science. He supported her in writing her bachelor's thesis, which was honored with the Zeiss Women Award. Previously, at Zaspel's suggestion, she had already been awarded the Deans Prize, with which Jacobs University recognizes outstanding theses by its students.

"Drishti's work has a level that is often not even reached in master's theses," Zaspel said. "It opens the door to a new field for upcoming work on data-driven methods in scientific visualization." At issue is a software program called ParaView that visualizes fluids such as blood or water. Drishti introduced novel features in ParaView by incorporating machine learning into the software.

Championing Low-Cost, High-Impact Climate Technology

VayuDrishti’s nomination marks a significant moment for Nepal’s growing climate-tech ecosystem. The startup has been pioneering affordable, data-driven air quality monitoring tools designed specifically for South Asia’s pollution-prone regions. Its innovations include:

Low-cost air quality monitoring devices

AI-powered forecasting models

Real-time air pollution dashboards

School-based environmental literacy programs  
Through this integrated system, VayuDrishti aims to make clean air a basic right, not a privilege limited to urban or high-income communities.

A Global Recognition of Nepal’s Innovation Capacity [...] UNV

Ecosphere News Correspondent

Kathmandu, Nepal - Nepal’s emerging climate-technology startup VayuDrishti has been selected as the official National Nominee for the 2025 World Summit Awards (WSA), positioning Nepal prominently on a prestigious global platform that honours impactful digital innovations.

The World Summit Awards, supported by UN initiatives, recognise digital solutions that meaningfully address global challenges across public health, environment, education, social inclusion, and public service delivery. Each member country nominates its best digital innovation, and VayuDrishti will now represent Nepal among competitors from more than 180 countries.

Championing Low-Cost, High-Impact Climate Technology [...] Moving Toward the Global Stage

As the national nominee, VayuDrishti will now enter the International Jury Round, where global digital innovation experts will assess its technological impact and scalability. Successful entries will advance to the Grand Jury and ultimately to the WSA Global Award stage.

The WSA 2025 winners are expected to be announced in early 2026, with finalists receiving international visibility, mentorship opportunities, and access to a UN-aligned network of global innovators.
